column4: Here's an easy question: is mplayer and standard Movie player that comes preinstalled with Ubuntu = same players?
no
just use a symlink
any special flags I should use?
no, ln -s TARGET NAME.  Or just rigth click -> create symlink (or whatever it says)
so?
it would be much easier to be able to navigate with "cd .." within my original dirname...
you probably just want to use an alias, I don't see your use case

no, not an alias.. my use case would be something like this: when I'm located in my ~/Downloads, I'd like to be able to quickly move files to different locations, such as "/var/www/home/sites/all/themes/mytheme/images"
what's wrong with using a symlink in that case?
or just store the long path in some variable and then do mv whatever_file $my_long_path

I'd use links for that - like "mv filename linkname", but when I "cd linkname", I'm not able to navigate throught my "/var/www" path with "cd .." - maybe I should use both... alias AND links... hmmm.. but it's just weird
well I think in zsh you can have cd aliases, but really I think your solution is to just save the path in some short variable...
well, that's not such an improvement comparing with symlinks... or am I missing something big here?
why not?  cd $my_path, mv whatever_file $my_path
you could ask #bash if there's a better way
oh, cd $my_path WILL work as I expect! right!
that doesn't do what you want...
I've been suggested on #bash
I understand, but you can't use that to move files, and you can't use it with cd.  It's about the same as having an alias
yes, I just tested it... bummer.
my applications?
all the applications I've installed on my Karmic
when you upgrade, they are kept
